content.description: A nice thin face climb that works the right side.  It starts on the upper ledge and works a little left then angles right in some thin cracks and then moves straight up.  The climbing is great, the pro is not.
content.protection: No anchors on top, so bring your slings and gear. Also as far as leading it goes, I would bring lots of small nuts and you would need to be fearless.

content.description: The furthest right line on the face, staying just left of a hole/ledge at mid-height.  Good rock and good climbing, a little vegetation if I remember correctly.
content.protection: No fixed gear at all, so set up your own anchors atop, using lots of slings.  I top-roped this one so no good beta on gear for the route

content.description: Another EZ TR setup.  Didn't lead it, so don't remember the gears.  Seemed nondescript, but while you're in the area...
content.protection: I'd guess rock protection for the most part.
content.location: Left edge of the face.  That's climber's left.

climbs.name: Buckets to Bangkok
climbs.fa: TR: Merril Bitter, Lead: Paul Smith and Pokey Armory 1984

content.description: The Bible calls this 12a R/X.  I'd emphasize the X if you sack up and give 'er a lead--likely this has seen very few over the years.  Fantastic thin slab face.  Hooting and hollering common when you latch the 1.5 pad "bucket" as it seems gargantuan compared to the crux holds.
content.protection:
See Brad's comment. Small fiddly bits.

Or TR with a gear anchor.
content.location: Smoothest part of the wall.  Start on a block.
